prior_works.title: Gaussian Differential Privacy
prior_works.authors: Jinshuo Dong, Aaron Roth, Weijie J. Su
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the f-DP tradeoff-function framework, composition, and conversions that the paper directly builds on to design PN-f-DP and Sec-f-LDP accounting in decentralized FL.

prior_works.title: Amplification by Shuffling: From Local to Central Differential Privacy
prior_works.authors: Úlfar Erlingsson, Vitaly Feldman, Ilya Mironov, Ananth Raghunathan, Kunal Talwar, Abhradeep Thakurta
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Inspires the paper’s use of network-mediated mixing/secrecy to obtain amplification—informing Sec-f-LDP’s structured, secret-based noise and the view that sparse, shuffled-like interactions can yield stronger central-style privacy.

prior_works.title: Randomized Gossip Algorithms
prior_works.authors: Stephen Boyd, Arpita Ghosh, Balaji Prabhakar, Devavrat Shah
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Supplies the random-walk/gossip communication paradigm that PN-f-DP models pairwise interactions over, enabling pairwise network privacy accounting tied to mixing behavior.

prior_works.title: Concentration inequalities for Markov chains by Marton couplings and spectral methods
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides concentration and mixing bounds for finite-state Markov chains that the paper leverages to quantify privacy amplification from sparse, random-walk communication in PN-f-DP.

prior_works.title: Practical Secure Aggregation for Privacy-Preserving Machine Learning
prior_works.authors: Keith Bonawitz, Vladimir Ivanov, Ben Kreuter, Antonio Marcedone, H. Brendan McMahan, Sarvar Patel, Daniel Ramage, Aaron Segal, Karn Seth
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Motivates the use of shared secrets/correlated randomness so that injected local noise cancels in aggregation, a key mechanism behind the paper’s Sec-f-LDP structured-noise accounting.

prior_works.title: Privacy Amplification by Subsampling: Tight Analyses via Couplings and Divergences
prior_works.authors: Borja Balle, James Bell, Adrià Gascón, Kobbi Nissim (often cited with Wang/Kairouz variants)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Establishes subsampling-based amplification principles that the paper adapts conceptually to sparse communication and local iterations within its f-DP accounting.

prior_works.title: Rényi Differential Privacy
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Serves as a key prior accounting framework and conversion target, informing comparisons and bridge results when translating decentralized mechanisms into f-DP guarantees.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core advance—f-DP–based privacy accounting tailored to decentralized federated learning—rests on unifying f-DP theory with the stochastic structure of peer-to-peer communication and correlated noise generation. Dong–Roth–Su’s Gaussian Differential Privacy supplies the foundational tradeoff-function calculus and composition laws that the authors adapt into PN-f-DP and Sec-f-LDP. To capture amplification from network sparsity and random-walk communication, the work models message passing through the lens of randomized gossip (Boyd et al.), then quantifies exposure using concentration inequalities for Markov chains (Paulin), converting mixing-time and visitation bounds into tightened f-DP tradeoff curves for pairwise interactions. The Sec-f-LDP mechanism draws on secure aggregation (Bonawitz et al.) to orchestrate shared secrets and correlated noise that cancel in aggregates, while still being analyzable under f-DP; conceptually, this is aligned with amplification-by-shuffling (Erlingsson et al.), where anonymity/mixing reduces effective privacy loss relative to local mechanisms. Amplification-by-subsampling results (Balle et al.) guide the treatment of sparse participation and local iterations as implicit subsampling events that further amplify privacy in decentralized protocols. Finally, Rényi DP (Mironov) provides an established accounting baseline and conversion pathway that contextualizes the proposed f-DP analyses and facilitates comparison to prior DP-SGD accounting practices. Together, these works enable a principled accounting framework that captures amplification from decentralized communication, local computation, and structured correlated noise.
